entry.title: Confluence XML Import Issues
entry.content:
Find the class that the import is having issues with. For this example ContentPermission is the problem.

Error while importing backup: not-null property references a null or transient value: com.atlassian.confluence.security.ContentPermission.owningSet
Caused by: net.sf.hibernate.PropertyValueException: not-null property references a null or transient value: com.atlassian.confluence.security.ContentPermission.owningSet

Delete all ContentPermission entries from the XML file – this will remove all unnecessary/unsupported classes and will allow the import to continue. Open the zip file and edit entities.xml


Search for <object class="ContentPermission"...> You will see <object> entries like this:

Helpful on-liner to remove the entries from entities.xml

Make sure there are no syntax errors that will cause the import to fail

xmllint --noout entities.xml

Retry the import and Good Luck!

entry.title: Apache Proxy Example
entry.content: Apache proxy example for web app running on myapp.website.com on port 7990.

entry.title: Cisco Catalyst 2960 - Notes
entry.content:
VLAN

Creating VLANs

Show all VLANs on switch

> sh vlan

Now, Let’s begin. Enter global configuration mode

# config t

Enter a VLAN ID

# vlan 5

Provide a name for the VLAN

# name myvlan

Exit config

# end

Assigning Ports to a VLAN

Enter global configuration mode

# config t

Select the interface (port). Naming convention: Switch# / Port

e.g Switch 1 port 19

# interface Gi1/0/19

Define the VLAN membership mode for the port (Layer 2 access port).

# switchport mode access

Assign the port to a VLAN

# switchport access vlan 5

Exit config

# end

Back up and Restore Configuration Files

TFTP Back up

To back up the current configuration, enter Privilege Mode then type the following:

#copy running-config tftp:

You will then be prompt to provided the address of the tftp server & the filename. Here is an example:

Address or name of remote host []? 102.10.15.44
 Destination filename [mco-confg]? name_of_config_file
 !!
 1030 bytes copied in 2.489 secs (395 bytes/sec)

TFTP Restore

To restore a configuration from a tftp server, first enter Privilege Mode then type the following:

#copy tftp: running-config

You will then be prompt to provided the address of the tftp server & the filename. Here is an example:

Address or name of remote host []? 102.10.15.44
 Source filename []? backup_cfg_for_my_router
 Destination filename [running-config]?
 Accessing tftp://102.10.15.1/backup_cfg_for_my_router...
 Loading backup_cfg_for_router from 102.10.15.44 (via FastEthernet0/0): !
 [OK - 1030 bytes]

entry.title: ERROR 2006 (HY000) MySQL Server Has Gone Away
entry.content:
The server’s default max_allowed_packet value is 1MB and it looks like it has exceeded the default max. You can increase this if the server needs to handle big queries. This can be done in two ways:

Start MySQL client with the following option (64 MB for this example)

mysql --max_allowed_packet=64M

or Add the following in your my.cnf file

max_allowed_packet=64M

entry.title: Temporarily Disable Puppet
entry.content:
This is can be done by an admin disabled of Puppet

# puppet agent --disable "Reason why disabled"

To make sure it’s disable, just do a Puppet run;

# puppet agent -t
 Notice: Skipping run of Puppet configuration client; administratively disabled (Reason: 'Testing some new things');
 Use 'puppet agent --enable' to re-enable.

To enable:

puppet agent --enable

entry.title: Confluence Backup Errors
entry.content:
The following error(s) occurred:
com.atlassian.confluence.importexport.ImportExportException: Couldn't backup database data. at com.atlassian.confluence.importexport.impl.AbstractXmlExporter.backupEntities(AbstractXmlExporter.java:197) at com.atlassian.confluence.importexport.impl.AbstractXmlExporter.backupEverything(AbstractXmlExporter.java:99) at com.atlassian.confluence.importexport.impl.FileXmlExporter.backupEverything(FileXmlExporter.java:76)

Java is running out of memory.

To increase heap or perm gen space memory in Linux installations,

Edit $CONFLUENCE_HOME/bin/setenv.sh

Find the section JAVA_OPTS="-Xms256m -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m and set accordingly.  Xmx is maximum, Xms is minimum, and MaxPermSize is PermGen.

entry.title: Git 1.8.x on CentOS
entry.content:
At the moment this is not on EPEL & CentOS repo, you’ll have to compile from source.

Get the desired version: http://code.google.com/p/git-core/downloads/list

tar -xzvf ./git-1.8.x.tar.gz
cd ./git-1.8.x
./configure
make && make install

entry.title: Configuring Memcached
entry.content:
What is memcached?

memcached is a high-performance, distributed memory object caching system, generic in nature, but originally intended for use in speeding up dynamic web applications by alleviating database load.

Configuring memcached

Edit

/etc/sysconfig/memcached

Sample configuration. Cache size is important, it determines the amount of ram in megabytes that are allocated to memcached pool.

PORT="11211"
USER="memcached"
MAXCONN="1024"
CACHESIZE="12288"
OPTIONS=""

entry.title: SVN Cat Error: "File Not Found". Gives Wrong Revision
entry.content:
You will need to use the peg revision

svn command -r OPERATIVE-REV item@PEG-REV

http://svnbook.red-bean.com/en/1.2/svn.advanced.pegrevs.html

entry.title: JIRA V5 SVN Commit Tab Error
entry.content:
JIRA v5 SVN commit tab error. com.atlassian.jira.plugin.ext.subversion:subversion-commits-tabpanel

To fix this issue you will need to remove the atlassian-subversion-revisions folder which is located under the home directory of the JIRA user.

$JIRA_HOME/caches/indexes/plugins/atlassian-subversion-revisions/

Now restart JIRA, the subversion tab should now start displaying commits.

 

source: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/How+to+resolve+JIRA+Sub+Version+Plugin+Errors+after+an+upgrade

entry.title: Flush Memcached
entry.content: echo 'flush_all' | nc localhost 11211

entry.title: Restored a Cleared Git Stash
entry.content:
Run the following:

git fsck --lost-found

You will get something similar to this:

Checking objects: 100% (6596/6596), done.
dangling commit e3b3b973asdasdasdasdasd7cqweqwe35f6d34e

Now just apply the stash’s SHA1:

git stash apply e3b3b973asdasdasdasdasd7cqweqwe35f6d34e

entry.title: Su Apache: "This Account Is Currently Not Available"
entry.content:
When trying to switch user to apache and you get the following: ”This account is currently not available”. You need to set a shell for the apache user. Let’s say we want to use bash.

# chsh -s /bin/bash apache

You should get this prompt:

Changing shell for apache.
Shell changed.

Done! Now you should be able to su as apache.

entry.title: SVN Backup & Migration
entry.content:
Backing Up

Backing up the D87 repo:

# svnadmin dump /var/svn/repos/D87 > D87_repo.svndump

Migrating a Repository

First back up the Repo (See steps above). Now create the repo in the new location.

e.g. D87 repo:

# svnadmin create /var/svn/repos/D87

Load the dump file created during the backup process

# svnadmin load /var/svn/repos/D87 < D87_repo.svndump

entry.title: VIM: Find & Replace
entry.content:
Find “foo” and replace with “hello”

:%s/foo/hello/g

entry.title: Examples of Lftp
entry.content:
In this example we are changing directory to “output” and doing a listing of files:

 lftp -e 'set net:timeout 10;cd output/;ls; bye' -u USER,PASSWORD ftp.foo.com/

Here we are going to “output” and we transferring ”myfile.txt” to our local /tmp directory.

lftp -e 'set net:timeout 10;cd output/;get myfile.txt -o /tmp/; bye' -u USER,PASSWORD ftp.foo.com/

entry.title: Puppet: Adding a Package
entry.content:
For this example lets ensure we have lftp install.

package { "lftp":
        ensure => "latest"
}

entry.title: Concatenate CAT
entry.content:
Let’s say we have two files, A.txt & B.txt. To show the output of these two files at once you will need to pipe cat using a “–”.

cat a.txt | cat - b.txt

entry.title: Chmod Directories and Files Separately
entry.content:
If you are looking to chmod directories and files separately, the find command can be of great help. Take a look at these examples:

For Directories:

find . -type d -exec chmod -v 775 {} \;

For Files:

find . -type f -exec chmod -v 664 {} \;

entry.title: MySQL High Load / Other Issues - Leap Second Bug
entry.content:
After struggling with a sever that was acting up, i did some investigating and found it to be related to a recent leap second that was added on June 30th. On Saturday midnight Greenwich Mean Time (GMT), an extra second was added to the Universal Coordinated Time (UTC). According to some news reports the Linux kernel has a bug in how it handles leap seconds.

The fix was simple:

 service ntpd stop

date -s "`date`"

service ntpd start
